subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... I spent a year in Germany and can speak German pretty well. I stayed in southern Germany. Your characterization is actually a great over simlification.
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:

>
> That's because German orthography is based on an artificial version
> of German that is nobody's native language: roughly speaking it has
> an older form of Southern grammar with very few Northern influences,
> but the orthography is pretty much Northern, or perhaps better,
> a Northerner's idea of how to pronounce a moderately Southern variety.
>

I spent a year in Germany and can speak German pretty well. I stayed in
southern Germany. Your characterization is actually a great over
simlification. Most German use so called "hoch Deutsch" to conversere
with one another. They would hardly call it an artificial language. It
is understood all over Germany and everyone can speak it with ease. It
also shows what can happen when a government takes spelling reform
seriously--you have a language that even Americans can spell, often
better than their own!

Paul

> 
> That's because German orthography is based on an artificial version
> of German that is nobody's native language: roughly speaking it has
> an older form of Southern grammar with very few Northern influences,
> but the orthography is pretty much Northern, or perhaps better,
> a Northerner's idea of how to pronounce a moderately Southern variety.
> 

I spent a year in Germany and can speak German pretty well. I stayed in 
southern Germany. Your characterization is actually a great over 
simlification. Most German use so called "hoch Deutsch" to conversere 
with one another. They would hardly call it an artificial language. It 
is understood all over Germany and everyone can speak it with ease. It 
also shows what can happen when a government takes spelling reform 
seriously--you have a language that even Americans can spell, often 
better than their own!
